content.body: Domenic: were you aware of https://github.com/w3c/aria/issues/1878?
annevk: yes. This came from a time when they had both string versions and element versions.
content.formatted_body: annevk: yes. This came from a time when they had both string versions and element versions.

content.body: I guess they didn't revisit the decision when the string versions were cut.
So many weird things there, also autoComplete ðŸ˜¢
I think the Element suffix is OK, it helps us if we ever want to spend the time retrofitting on Element versions of existing idref reflected attributes
Okay, happy to drop it

Domenic: so does https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#attr-autocapitalize not use reflect because browsers don't have reflect architecture that can cope? It seems that with canonical keyword that would actually be possible
content.formatted_body: Domenic: so does https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#attr-autocapitalize not use reflect because browsers don't have reflect architecture that can cope? It seems that with canonical keyword that would actually be possible

content.body: Domenic: my current thinking is that the values go in an IDL enum and a separate list would have the states, but only if needed (or perhaps instead we'd write some "getter helper steps" for the couple of attributes that need some kind of normalization steps; it'd still be a lot of work though
content.formatted_body: Domenic: my current thinking is that the values go in an IDL enum and a separate list would have the states, but only if needed (or perhaps instead we'd write some "getter helper steps" for the couple of attributes that need some kind of normalization steps; it'd still be a lot of work though

krosylight: hey, wanted to double check something, did you include tests for request streams with byte reading?
That kinda landed earlier with https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/37910

content.body: Oh, you mean Requests?

krosylight: could you add some? It's impacted due to extract and it also makes sense for it to be impacted as we support both request and response streams at a specification level (even more officially since adding the `duplex` member in July last year)
